There must be lots of debate topics more pleasant than that of race, but I was asked to address the issue of why black rates of street crime are higher than for other groups, so here goes. 
 
 There are a number of theories on the subject; let me go from the most popular among criminologists (that means most liberal) to the least popular. 
 
 The most popular explanation focuses on America and argues that crime is produced by a culture that demands economic success of everyone in a society where such a goal cannot be reached by some. The strain caused by the pressure to succeed when there is a lack of opportunity to do so leads people to turn to crime in desperation as a way to achieve the American Dream.
 
 The problem with this theory is that research has revealed that America, a country that should produce much strain and thus crime, does not have a high rate of property crimes, the very crimes that enrich a person the most. 
 The U.S. is similar to other countries in property-related crimes. Where America (and American blacks) stick out is with violent crime--crimes that generally are not profitable. The typical murder involves an argument between two guys over some trivial matter, and the murder profits you nothing. 
 
 Another problem with this theory is the basic criminological finding that criminals are "generalists"; that is, they commit a very wide range of illegal and legal but irresponsible acts. Not only do they steal, they vandalize; they assault adults and children and rape women (and sometimes men); they get addicted to drugs and gambling and wild, reckless living; they have work records of unreliability; and they have unstable relationships. Strain theory presents the image of an ambitious guy who just needs a chance, but criminals are short-term hedonists. 
 
 Where the theory is more credible is with drug dealing which can be very profitable, especially for a youth who otherwise will be flipping burgers for minimum wage. The vast majority of street dealers never achieve the long-term wealth symbolized by the American Dream, but it can get some guys big money quickly. 
 
 A more realistic theory might focus more on a subculture which has developed in poor black communities of flashy conspicuous consumption and has glamorized not only the money and things but the status and glamor of the gangster. With many blacks at the margins of society, this kind of alternative culture may have developed in contrast to the orginal image of the theory of poor people just wanting mainstream respectability that wealth could give.
 
 Strain theory was designed to explain property crime, but where blacks have especially high rates is with serious violence, so more recent theorists have presented at least two revisions of the theory. First, oppressive treatment of blacks, especially unfair in a society preaching eqaulity, has produced a diffuse rage and resentment among blacks. That rage is a general feeling, not necessarily directed at anyone, but it gets taken out on convenient targets, usually other blacks.
 
 A problem with this theory, like strain theory, is that it is designed to explain the situation in the U.S., but the reality of high levels of black violent crime is found in any country that has data on the issue. WHO, INTERPOL, and victimization survey data all indicate that rates of violent crime are high among blacks in Canada, or Britain; in all predominantly black Caribbean countries; and in black African countries. 
 
 One could argue that oppression in those countries could have them same effect there, but the high rates are found, not matter how absent whites are from the society, and no matter matter the level of white domination. For example, South African violent crime has escalation in tandem with reforms there. This theory would predict a decrease in violent crime as white domination receded. The same is true in the U.S. During the 1960s and 1970s, we saw the the cause of civil rights advance; at the same time there was a crime explosion. 
 
 Another version of the theory, since people are far from satisfied with the original, is that black crime rates increased 1960-1994 because inquality grew between lower-class blacks and middle-class BLACKS. As the latter moved into middle-class lifestyles, lower-class blacks were left behind, and this is the source of their resentment. A theory like this may be consistent with a specific historical trend, but the problem with these theories is that they fail to be general enough to explain the worldwide pattern. 
 
 Social learning theory contends that marginalized communties develop subcultures favorable to crime, and so there develop powerful gangs which compete with the decent people of the neighborhood for the loyalty of the children. Some children will fall under their influence and will socialized into the gang. 
 
 The problem with this theory, along with others, is that it views all kids as the same and as passive sponges who either have good luck and avoid the gang's influence or have bad luck and fall into it. Research shows that small children and school-age children who have serious behavior problems are more likely than other children to be involved in serious crime 20 or 30 years down the road. Sociological theories like social learning ignore the fact the children get on a path toward criminality at the earliest of ages. So any valid theory must incorporate this finding. 
 
 Another theory claims that crime is the product of neighborhood with weak, disorganized institutions, especially those that socialize children. So crime grows rampant where the families, schools, churches, community orgs., and businesses are failing at their jobs of socializing and supervising young people. Research clearly shows that crime is rampant in these kinds of neighborhoods, but the analyses are always done at a macro-level, so we don't know, for example, if it's the kids not going to church who are breaking the law or not. These studies don't rule out the possiblity that these neighborhoods have higher numbers of people with certain traits who are prone to criminality. This trait theory may not be true, but it cannot be ruled out with these kinds of studies. 
 
 Related to this disorganization theory is the idea that blacks have high crime rates because they have high levels of family instability and this problem is very concentrated in poor black neighborhoods, so you'll have say 80% of families with dad not around all living together on the same block. Such a condition causes families and neighborhoods to lose control of young people. Research generally shows that if you control for family structure, the black-crime correlation at the neighborhood level often disappears, but once again we don't know if its the characteristics of the neighborhood that is causing the problem or that the neighborhood has a higher number of people with traits conducive to crime (and other social problems). 
 
 The last two theories are generally politically unacceptable to criminologists, so they usually don't study them--at least as they relate to explaining balck crime. The first is self-control theory which claims that crime is the result of not correcting children consistently when they misbehave, so they grow up not developing the habit of considering the long-term consquences of bad behavior or how it hurts others. According to this theory, newborn babies are naturally self-focused and can only thinking about getting their needs met right now. The habit of thinking of others and the future has to be taught to children over the long haul of childhood, through thousands of learning opportunities. Criminals never effectively learn this and lead lives of impulsivity, pleasure-seeking, shortcut-hunting, and irresponsibility. 
 
 The research finding that criminals engage in a wide variety of destructive behavior is consistent with this theory, as is the fact the serious behvaior problems short very early, are shown early in school through defiance of teachers, bullying, aggression, stealing, vandalism, lying, etc. And the problems continue right into adulthood. The theory cannot explain everything however; impulsivity, low self-control, risk-taking, intelligence, etc.--all these kinds of traits are certainly related to crime but far from perfectly. 
 
 More specifically for this thread, I haven't seen the theory tested to explain the racial difference in crime. If this theory were true, implied is that black families tend to be less effective at consistently correcting misbehavior on the part of their children. It is well documented that family problems are more common in black families, and some research indicates that black children tend to receive less supervision, but people simply do not like to consider this possibilty, so it has not been studied much. 
 
 Even less politically acceptable is the theory that average differences in biology account for race differences in crime. This is a totally taboo subject and is generally not studied, especially in any direct way. Twins studies do show such traits as aggression, impulsivity, risk-taking, callousness, lack of altruism, narcissism, intelligence etc., are substantially influenced by genes, but this is far from direct evidence that racial differences are explained by different frequencies in these traits. Some have argued that antisocial personality disorder--partly genetic in origin--occurs more often in blacks, but the research has not been done from what I have seen. Research has shown that blacks tend to have higher levels of testosterone--shown to be related to aggressiveness--than other groups, one reason for their higher rates of prostate cancer. 
 
 A biological theory is the one theory that could most easily explain the high rates of crime in countries all around the world, but in one study in Criminology by Neopolitan, he eliminated the race-crime correlation by controlling for several social factors. The biological people, on the other hand, would argue that the genetic composition of population produces its social conditions which in turn produce behavior like crime, so the social factors simply mediate the effects of genes. Most social scientists refuse to study these claims, even with the motivation to disprove them, so the facts are simply scarce. 
 
 A genetic explanation, for instance, cannot explain trends like the explosion of street crime in the U.S. during the 60s,70s, and 80s, nor its decline in the second half of the 90s. 
 
 Anyway, like always in social science, there is no simple answer. No theory seems to handle all the facts.
